question.title: Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?
question.body:
This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

[image]

user_prompts:
QUESTIONS: {'P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('6857a564-206b-496f-906b-491873861a5c'), title='Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?', body='This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

(b) Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during 2024?', body='This market will resolve YES if either of the following conditions is met: (1) Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024; (2) Elon Musk publicly discusses Bitcoin in any capacity during the year 2024, regardless of the platform or medium.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 12, 31, 23, 59, 59, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=False), 'Q_and_not_P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('1ead077d-f9de-40b9-b01d-6f4cc13b5563'), title='Will both of the following occur: (1) Elon Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin during 2024 (2) Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?', body='This question will resolve YES if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Elon Musk publicly discusses Bitcoin in any capacity during the year 2024, regardless of the platform or medium, and (2) Elon Musk does not become a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 12, 31, 23, 59, 59, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'Q_given_P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('e7a06294-2a56-4049-80ae-bc088c1c9e55'), title='Given Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, will he make a public statement about Bitcoin during 2024?', body='This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

This question will resolve YES if Elon Musk publicly discusses Bitcoin in any capacity during the year 2024, regardless of the platform or medium.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 12, 31, 23, 59, 59, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='conditional_binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None)}

GENERAL: Output your general reasoning and thought process.  Here you can be as detailed as you want, mentioning the reasoning of your predictions and how / why each prediction obeys the given consistency rules.  If there are multiple questions P, Q, you can also make comments on their independence or relationship with each other.

PROB: Output your probability estimates of each of the variables (P, Q, not_P, etc.).  Here, ONLY output the labels, their associated predictions, and NOTHING ELSE. Your output MUST look and be formatted as follows.
    P: 0.xx,
    not_P: 0.xx,
    P_or_Q: 0.xx,
    ...

CHECK: Go through each rule in CONSISTENCY RULES and check whether each rule is obeyed with your given predictions.  For each rule, first print the mathematical rule and the associated predicted values associated with it.  Then think VERY carefully about whether the outputs obey the mathematical rule. Then output whether it obeys the rule. At the end, print out a summary on whether all of the rules passed, or which ones failed. Your output MUST look and be formatted as follows.
    neg: P = 1- not_P, EQUATION is EVALUATION, 
    andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, EQUATION is EVALUATION, 
    and:  max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), EQUATION is EVALUATION,
    ...
    {ALL consistency checks passed!} OR {failed_check_1, failed_check_2 ... consistency checks failed!

PROB: Now again output your probability estimates of each variable in a dict like format like before, but taking account and correcting any consistency violations that occurred.
        Note that changing the predicted probability of one value to satisfy one consistency rule will also affect consistency rules for others.  It is IMPERATIVE that any changes made still ensure all other consistency checks pass too.
        If there were no violations found, then simply output the same dict again.  Your output MUST look like and be formatted as follows.
        P: 0.xx,
        not_P: 0.xx,
        P_or_Q: 0.xx,
        ...
FLOAT: Now just output your probability estimate of P and nothing else as a decimal!

Q_and_not_P: 0.10
Q_given_P: 0.32

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.73 = 1 - 0.27 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.73 = 0.83 + 0.23 - 0.33 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.73, + 0.33 - 1, 0) <= 0.23 <= min(0.73, 0.33) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.73, 0.33) <= 0.83 <= min(1, 0.73 + 0.33) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.73 = 0.83 - 0.10 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.73 ≈ 0.23 / 0.32 is TRUE
para: P = para_P, 0.73 = 0.73 is TRUE

andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.73 = 0.71 + 0.23 - 0.33 is FALSE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.73 + 0.33 - 1, 0) <= 0.23 <= min(0.73, 0.33) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.73, 0.33) <= 0.71 <= min(1, 0.73 + 0.33) is FALSE

P: 0.73
not_P: 0.27
para_P: 0.73
Q: 0.33
P_and_Q: 0.23
P_or_Q: 0.83
Q_and_not_P: 0.10
Q_given_P: 0.32

0.73

RECEIVED

For the given questions, we need to assess the probabilities related to Elon Musk's participation in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 event and his public statements regarding Bitcoin in 2024. 

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: Given Elon Musk's high profile, his attendance at such a significant event is likely, although contingent on various factors such as schedule and interest in Bitcoin at that time. A reasonable estimate might be around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is simply the complement of P, so if P is 0.65, then not_P would be 0.35.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is essentially the same as P, so it should also be around 0.65.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during 2024?)**: Given Musk's history of engaging with Bitcoin, I would estimate this probability to be around 0.70, as he is likely to comment on Bitcoin again given its ongoing relevance.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both occur: (a) Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 and (b) makes a public statement about Bitcoin during 2024?)**: Assuming P and Q are somewhat independent, we can estimate this as P * Q, which would be around 0.65 * 0.70 = 0.455.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either of the following occur: (a) Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024? (b) Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin during 2024?)**: This can be calculated using the formula P + Q - P_and_Q, which would be 0.65 + 0.70 - 0.455 = 0.895.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both occur: (1) Elon Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin during 2024 (2) Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This scenario is a bit trickier as it combines Q with not_P. Assuming some independence, this could be estimated as Q * not_P, which would be 0.70 * 0.35 = 0.245.

8. **Q_given_P (Given Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, will he make a public statement about Bitcoin during 2024?)**: If he attends, the likelihood of him making a statement about Bitcoin would likely increase. So, I would estimate this probability to be higher, around 0.80.

After estimating these probabilities, we will need to check them against the consistency rules provided to ensure they fit within the logical framework established.

P: 0.65,
not_P: 0.35,
para_P: 0.65,
Q: 0.70,
P_and_Q: 0.46,
P_or_Q: 0.89,
Q_and_not_P: 0.25,
Q_given_P: 0.80

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.65 = 1 - 0.35 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.65 = 0.89 + 0.46 - 0.70 is FALSE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.65 + 0.70 - 1, 0) <= 0.46 <= min(0.65, 0.70) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.65, 0.70) <= 0.89 <= min(1, 0.65 + 0.70) is FALSE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.65 = 0.89 - 0.25 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.65 ≈ 0.46 / 0.80 is FALSE
para: P = para_P, 0.65 = 0.65 is TRUE

neg, andor, or, cond consistency checks failed!

not_P: 0.35,
para_P: 0.65,
Q: 0.70,
P_and_Q: 0.45,
P_or_Q: 0.85,
Q_and_not_P: 0.25,
Q_given_P: 0.80

0.65

In evaluating the probability estimates for the events surrounding Elon Musk's potential appearance at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 and his public statements about Bitcoin in 2024, I considered various factors that could influence these outcomes. 

1. **P (Elon Musk showing up at Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This event could depend on Musk's interest in Bitcoin and his general engagement with the cryptocurrency community. Given his historical involvement with Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies, I estimate a moderate probability of him attending the event.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk not showing up at Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is the complement of P, and its probability will be derived from the estimate of P. If P is estimated at, say, 0.60, then not_P would be 1 - 0.60 = 0.40.

3. **para_P (Chance of Elon Musk attending)**: This is closely related to P, and I believe it should have a similar probability since both questions address the same event from slightly different angles.

4. **Q (Public statement about Bitcoin during 2024)**: Musk's engagement with Bitcoin could lead to public statements, especially given the increasing interest in cryptocurrency. I estimate this probability based on trends in cryptocurrency discussions and Musk's past behavior.

5. **P_and_Q (Both showing up and making a statement)**: This requires both events to occur, so I expect this probability to be lower than either P or Q, but not significantly lower if I believe there's a strong correlation between them.

6. **P_or_Q (Either showing up or making a statement)**: This probability should be higher than both P and Q individually, as it covers either scenario.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Making a statement while not showing up)**: This scenario is plausible and should be given a moderate probability, as Musk can still make statements without attending the event.

8. **Q_given_P (Making a statement given he shows up)**: This conditional probability would likely be high, as attendance at the event would likely increase the chances of him making a public statement.

In terms of independence, P and Q are somewhat related but not entirely dependent on each other, as Musk could make statements without attending the conference and vice versa. 

Overall, I will need to ensure that the probabilities assigned adhere to the consistency rules provided, particularly the relationships between P, not_P, P_and_Q, and P_or_Q.

not_P: 0.40,
para_P: 0.60,
Q: 0.70,
P_and_Q: 0.42,
P_or_Q: 0.88,
Q_and_not_P: 0.28,
Q_given_P: 0.75

andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.60 = 0.88 + 0.42 - 0.70 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.60 + 0.70 - 1, 0) <= 0.42 <= min(0.60, 0.70) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.60, 0.70) <= 0.88 <= min(1, 0.60 + 0.70) is FALSE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.60 = 0.88 - 0.28 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.60 ≈ 0.42 / 0.75 is TRUE
para: P = para_P, 0.60 = 0.60 is TRUE
ALL consistency checks passed!

question.title: Will OpenAI publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, OpenAI publishes a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

RECEIVED

In this scenario, we are evaluating the probabilities related to Elon Musk's involvement in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference and his public statements about Bitcoin during 2024. The questions can be broken down as follows:

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This event is likely influenced by Musk's interest in Bitcoin and previous engagements at similar events. Given that he has shown interest in cryptocurrencies, I would estimate a moderate to high probability for this event, around 0.60.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: Since this is the negation of P, it should be complementary. Thus, not_P would be estimated at 0.40.

3. **para_P (Chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is essentially the same as P, so it will have the same probability estimate of 0.60.

4. **Q (Elon Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin during 2024)**: Given Musk's history of discussing Bitcoin and the increasing interest in cryptocurrencies, I would estimate a probability of 0.75 for this event.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: The occurrence of both events is dependent, but not perfectly correlated. I would estimate this at 0.45, reflecting a reasonable overlap between the two events.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This combines the probabilities of P and Q, but also accounts for their intersection. Thus, I would estimate this at 0.85, as it is likely at least one of the two events will occur.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs, but P does not)**: This scenario is plausible if Musk discusses Bitcoin without attending the conference. I would estimate this at 0.30.

8. **Q_given_P (Q occurs given that P occurs)**: If Musk attends the conference, the probability that he will make a statement about Bitcoin likely increases. I would estimate this at around 0.80.

Overall, I expect that the events are somewhat correlated, with P and Q likely affecting one another. However, they are not entirely dependent, allowing for the possibility of one occurring without the other. I will ensure that the estimates respect the consistency rules provided.

For the questions regarding Elon Musk's potential appearances and statements related to Bitcoin, I will assess the probabilities based on various factors, including past behavior, public interest, and the significance of the events in question.

1. **P (Elon Musk showing up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: Given Musk's history of engaging with the Bitcoin community and attending significant events, I estimate a moderate to high probability of him showing up at this conference. 

2. **not_P (Elon Musk not showing up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is simply the complement of P. If I estimate P at a certain level, not_P will be 1 minus that probability.

3. **para_P (Chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is essentially the same as P, so I will assign it the same probability.

4. **Q (Elon Musk making a public statement about Bitcoin during 2024)**: Considering the ongoing interest in Bitcoin and Musk's active role in discussions around it, I will assign a reasonable probability that he will make at least one public statement about Bitcoin in 2024.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occurring)**: This requires both events to happen. Since there is a possibility that Musk could attend the conference and also make a statement, I will estimate this probability to be lower than either individual probability but still significant.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurring)**: This will be a higher probability than either P or Q alone, as it encompasses both possibilities happening.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurring while not P)**: This is a more specific scenario where Musk makes a public statement but does not attend the conference. I will estimate this based on the likelihood of Q happening independently of P.

8. **Q_given_P (Q occurring given P)**: This conditional probability will be evaluated based on the assumption that if Musk attends the conference, he is more likely to make a statement about Bitcoin.

Next, I will assign numerical probabilities to these variables while ensuring they adhere to the consistency rules provided.
